file_metadata.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]
file_metadata.title: Planarians: A Versatile and Powerful Model System for Molecular Studies of Regeneration, Adult Stem Cell Regulation, Aging, and Behavior

chunks.text: Planarians are gaining recognition as a powerful model organism for molecular studies of complex biological processes like tissue regeneration, stem cell regulation, tissue turnover, drug action, cancer, and aging, with *Schmidtea mediterranea* being a prominent species.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarians, especially *S. mediterranea*, are valuable model organisms for studying various biological processes.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Resources for planarian research include protocols for colony maintenance, RNA interference, live imaging, and genome databases for *S. mediterranea* and *Dugesia ryukyuensis*, facilitating molecular studies.
chunks.chunk_summary: Various resources, including protocols and databases, are available for planarian research.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Planarians are basal triploblastic organisms with bilateral symmetry and encephalization, known for their regenerative capacity and adult stem cells (neoblasts), making them valuable for studying regeneration and stem cell biology.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarians' regenerative capacity and stem cells make them ideal for studying regeneration and stem cell biology.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Planarian research has a long history, with early work by Morgan and Randolph on regeneration, and modern research focusing on species like *S. mediterranea* and *Dugesia japonica* due to their regenerative properties and available molecular tools.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian research has a rich history, with modern studies focusing on specific species and molecular approaches.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: *Schmidtea mediterranea*, with both asexual and sexual strains, is a preferred species for molecular studies due to its regenerative properties, karyological features, and relatively small genome size.
chunks.chunk_summary: *S. mediterranea* is a valuable model organism for molecular studies due to its unique characteristics.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: The asexual and sexual strains of *S. mediterranea* differ in chromosomal translocation and reproductive mode, with the asexual strain reproducing by fission and the sexual strain requiring cross-fertilization.
chunks.topic: Asexual and sexual strains of *S. mediterranea*
chunks.chunk_summary: The asexual and sexual strains of *S. mediterranea* have distinct reproductive mechanisms.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: The asexual CIW4 and sexual S2F2 clonal lines of *S. mediterranea* were established for research, enabling studies on regeneration, embryonic development, and genome sequencing.
chunks.chunk_summary: Clonal lines of *S. mediterranea* have been established for research purposes.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Detailed protocols for establishing and maintaining planarian colonies are available.
chunks.chunk_summary: Protocols for planarian husbandry are available for researchers.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: *Dugesia japonica* is another planarian species used in regenerative biology research, with established clonal lines and protocols for techniques like whole-mount in situ hybridization and neoblast purification.
chunks.chunk_summary: *D. japonica* is another valuable planarian model for regenerative biology research.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Planarians are versatile model organisms suitable for various research areas, including tissue regeneration, cellular turnover, aging, stem cell biology, germ cell specification, memory, learning, and behavior, due to their ease of maintenance and amenability to different experimental techniques.
chunks.section: Uses of the Planarian Model System
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarians are versatile models for various research areas due to their ease of use and amenability to different techniques.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Planarians' ability to regenerate missing body parts and adjust their size, along with their continuous tissue renewal, makes them excellent models for studying regeneration, morphogenesis, growth regulation, and aging.
chunks.section: Tissue Regeneration, Cellular Turnover, and Aging
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarians' regenerative capacity and continuous tissue renewal make them valuable for studying regeneration, growth, and aging.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Planarians' reproductive system, including germ cell specification and gonad regeneration, offers insights into epigenetic mechanisms and the plasticity of germ cell development.
chunks.section: Tissue Regeneration, Cellular Turnover, and Aging
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarians' reproductive system provides a unique opportunity to study germ cell specification and regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Neoblasts, planarian stem cells, are crucial for tissue regeneration, germ cell specification, and tissue remodeling, and their regulation is a key area of research.
chunks.chunk_summary: Neoblasts, planarian stem cells, are essential for regeneration and their regulation is a key research focus.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: The molecular basis of germ cell specification in adult planarians, proposed to be epigenetically regulated, is an area of active investigation, with resources like EST databases aiding in identifying germ cell markers and signaling pathways.
chunks.chunk_summary: Germ cell specification in planarians is thought to be epigenetically regulated and is being actively studied.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Planarians, with their bilaterally symmetrical CNS and sensory capabilities, are valuable for studying neural patterning, behavior, memory, and the impact of stem cells on memory.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarians are useful for studying neural patterning, behavior, and memory due to their simple CNS and sensory capabilities.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Genetic nomenclature guidelines for *S. mediterranea* have been proposed to standardize gene and protein naming, facilitating homology identification and experimental consistency.
chunks.chunk_summary: Standardized genetic nomenclature for *S. mediterranea* has been proposed for consistency and clarity.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Genomic resources for *S. mediterranea*, including the SmedGD database, provide information on DNA sequences, predicted genes, ESTs, protein homologies, gene expression patterns, and RNAi phenotypes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Various genomic resources, including the SmedGD database, are available for *S. mediterranea* research.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Various molecular techniques, including mRNA purification, antibody staining, in situ hybridization, and quantitative RT-PCR, are used in planarian research, along with methods like Î³-irradiation and BrdU labeling for studying neoblasts.
chunks.chunk_summary: Various molecular techniques are employed in planarian research, including methods for studying neoblasts.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Planarians are suitable for studying drug effects, physiological processes, and electromagnetic stimulation due to their regenerative capacity and real-time analysis capabilities.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarians are useful for studying drug effects and physiological processes due to their regenerative capacity.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: Automated systems are being used for behavioral experiments in planarians, enabling high-throughput approaches and quantitative analysis.
chunks.chunk_summary: Automated systems are enhancing behavioral experiments in planarians.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: The authors acknowledge funding support from various sources, including NIH, NSF, NHTSA, and NIDCR, and express gratitude for facility renovations supported by NIH.
chunks.chunk_summary: The authors acknowledge funding support and express gratitude for facility renovations.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]

chunks.text: The references section lists the cited works in the paper.
chunks.chunk_summary: The references section provides a list of cited works.
chunks.authors: ["Nestor J. Oviedo", "Cindy S. Nicolas", "Michael Levin", "Dany S. Adams"]
